citation.article-title: Clostridium tagluense sp. nov., a psychrotolerant, anaerobic, spore-forming bacterium from permafrost.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Clostridium tagluense sp. nov.
Clostridium tagluense (tag.lu.en′se. N.L. neut. adj. tagluense after the Taglu gas-hydrate field in the Northwest Territories of Canada, the source of isolation of the type strain).
Cells are Gram-positive, motile rods with rounded ends (1.0–1.2×3–10 μm), occurring singly or in pairs.
Endospores are spherical, located in a subterminal position.
Colonies on PY agar are round, convex, cream-coloured and 1–2 mm in diameter.
Nitrate and sulfate are not reduced.
The temperature optimum for growth is 15–20 °C; the lower growth limit is 4 °C and the upper growth limit is 28 °C.
Grows at pH 6.0–8.0 (optimum pH 6.5–7.2) and in NaCl concentrations between 0 and 12–14 % (w/v) (optimum 0–2.0 %).
Under optimal conditions, the doubling time is 12.7 h.
Fermentable compounds include fumarate, malate, trypticase, betaine, choline, glucose, maltose, fructose, trehalose and starch.
Xylose, xylan, arabinose, cellobiose, lactose, mannose, sucrose, ribose, raffinose, rhamnose, melibiose, melezitose, inositol, mannitol and salicin do not support growth.
Gelatin is hydrolysed, but starch is not.
Major fermentation products formed in PY broth are acetate, butyrate, valerate, H2 and CO2.
The cell-wall peptidoglycan contains meso-diaminopimelic acid.
Major cellular fatty acids are C16 : 1 cis9 DMA, C16 : 1 cis9, C16 : 0 and C14 : 0.
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 31.5 mol%.
The type strain, A121T (=VKM B-2369T =DSM 17763T), was isolated from a permafrost sample from the core of the borehole 92GSCTaglu in the Mackenzie Delta, Northwest Territories, Canada.
